user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_equal_quoted_bin_n:
```c
bool
MHD_str_equal_quoted_bin_n (const char *quoted,
                            size_t quoted_len,
                            const char *unquoted,
                            size_t unquoted_len)
{
  size_t i;
  size_t j;
  if (unquoted_len < quoted_len / 2)
    return false;

  j = 0;
  for (i = 0; quoted_len > i && unquoted_len > j; ++i, ++j)
  {
    if ('\\' == quoted[i])
    {
      i++; /* Advance to the next character */
      if (quoted_len == i)
        return false; /* No character after escaping backslash */
    }
    if (quoted[i] != unquoted[j])
      return false; /* Different characters */
  }
  if ((quoted_len != i) || (unquoted_len != j))
    return false; /* The strings have different length */

  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
for (i = 0; quoted_len > i && unquoted_len > j; ++i, ++j)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The for header uses two loop counters and the counter is modified in the body. The loop header is: for (i = 0; quoted_len > i && unquoted_len > j; ++i, ++j). Both i and j are incremented in the third clause (violates the requirement that only one loop counter be present and that the third clause modify only the loop counter). Furthermore i is also modified inside the loop body (i++ when '\' is encountered), which violates the rule that the loop counter shall not be modified in the loop body. The second clause also uses j (not a single Boolean loop-control flag) while j is modified by the loop control, so the loop is not well‑formed under Rule 14.2.
